utterances: And he seems to have change his mind over the past couple of weeks, not just campaigning in Iowa personally, although he's made a couple of trips to New Hampshire as well, but never - but pouring a lot of money into the race, both for himself and through the Super PAC.
Well, and there seems to be some pent-up demand to see him now that he's actually here, so his crowds are quite are big.
And that - those may be people who have a different first choice candidate but they want to be sure that they give him at least one look.
And then, we're going to New Hampshire in next week.
And, of course, our Political Junkie will be in New Hampshire on Wednesday as we look at race there.
Of course, we'll be looking at the results from Iowa, as well, but that's a very different electorate.
It's a very different electorate and it's a very different race.
One of the polls we did Iowa was - we had a companion poll in New Hampshire, this was for Bloomberg News.
And we looked at the results, and Iowa was fascinating.
Everything seemed to be moving and changing.
And New Hampshire just seems so static and just nothing really moving up there.
So I know that some of the candidates are leaving Iowa and skipping New Hampshire to go directly to South Carolina.
It is a different kind of electorate.
It's a primary, so things lock in a little bit earlier.
You know, it is a more moderate state.
It's less influence of social conservatives.
And open primary, so independents can vote in the Republican primary as well.
But keep in mind, Neal, if you're an independent - if you're a registered Democrat, you can show up on caucus night and caucus for the Republicans.
You just have to change your registration.
And you say some people are skipping New Hampshire.

Mitt Romney, of course, governor in the neighboring state of Massachusetts, has a home in New Hampshire, is the, you know, you hate to use this word, but prohibitive favorite at the moment in New Hampshire as a substantial lead in any case.
And some of the more socially conservative candidates may be skipping New Hampshire to go on to South Carolina, which maybe more fertile ground.
Or perhaps try to master the withering stare.
Exactly.
I think that there are candidates who took a look at Iowa and thought - I'm a good fit to win Iowa.
And those are not the same candidates who look at New Hampshire and say I'm a good fit for New Hampshire.

I think most obviously it would be Mitt Romney, but also Jon Huntsman takes a look at New Hampshire and thinks that that might be a place for him, and that's where he's put all of his eggs in that basket.

A candidate like Newt Gingrich might think that while he might do well in Iowa, that he could also do well in New Hampshire but it seems like the field sort of divides between the Iowa type of candidate and the New Hampshire type of candidate.
And just as you keep those charts from 2004 around, some others might look to 2008 and remind everybody that Barack Obama, heavily favored to win in New Hampshire, until the actual day of the voting.
So things can change quickly there as well.
Yes.
So as we look at this final poll, you know, how much do you think it can change over the two days between the end of your polling and the actual caucuses?
Well, you know, there's a little bit of the secret world of the pollster.
As we're looking at those numbers night by night and we're getting ready to take them down to the newspaper, so they can start writing the stories.

And I will admit to you that I took out a pen and sort of made a dotted line of the trajectories as they were happening, kind of, saying, OK, well, how many - with two more days, how could this end up?
We have no way of judging because the campaigns really are tying to influence those numbers.
You know, if everything were just equal and in a vacuum, there's a chance that Rick Santorum could end up being the winner.
We're talking with Ann Selzer, president of Selzer & Company.
Thanks very much for your time.
We'll have to see how things come out Tuesday night.
Always my pleasure to be with you, Neal.
Ann Selzer, polls for the Des Moines register and Bloomberg.
She joins us from the studios at Iowa Public Radio in Des Moines.
From the studios of NPR West, this is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Coming up, details about the recent violence in and around Tibet and what's behind it.
First, though, to the economy, where the news these days is either confusing or bad or both.
And more today.
The index of leading economic indicators, that a gauge of future economic activity, has slipped for the fifth consecutive month.
What started a crisis in the housing industry has spread throughout the economy, which raises the question for all of us fretting about it: How exactly did this happen?

And that was the question that David Leonhardt, the economics columnist for the New York Times, took on in yesterday's column, and he made more sense writing there of what has gone wrong than anything we've read in months, and so we called him.
David Leonhardt, thank you for being with us on DAY TO DAY.
Thank you.

So you begin by saying you've talked to a lot of people on Wall Street even who don't quite understand how things have gotten so bad and why people are suddenly so worried, and you say really you do have to go back to the housing crisis, which started, well, the roots are back in 1998, when everyone was beginning to buy again.
That's right.
We had a real estate bust in this country in the early and mid-'90s, and then in the mid to late '90s the economy started to take off.
Incomes were rising, the stock market was soaring, cities were becoming much more pleasant places to live.
And it wasn't until the late '90s that real estate started to catch up and people realized, wait a minute, homes are now a bargain.
And they started buying.
So housing looks kind of cheap, and then the mortgage industry is beginning to change.
They have more buyers out there, more people - they need loans.
And so the industry does - well, what?

Well, so they - not only do they have more people wanting loans, but there's also a real influx of money coming from all over the world looking for profit, money from oil-producing countries like Russia and Saudi Arabia, money from China and India, which are booming, is circling the world looking for returns.
And much of it ends up coming to the United States and ends up coming into the mortgage market, and as a result the mortgage market becomes more competitive, which is in many ways a good thing.
It lowered mortgage fees, and it allowed people to get some mortgages that in the past they wouldn't have been able to get, but those good things fairly quickly led to excess.
The thing is, there was a great history because nationwide, as you write, the entire American housing market had never declined.
Nationwide, it had never actually turned sour.
So this looked like a good, safe investment.
It did, and in some ways, actually, the more important thing than that statistic, which I used in the column, is the fact that people kept repeating it.
There are a number of reasons why it's a little bit of a misleading statistic.

Prices had declined when you control them for inflation, which is really the more accurate way to look at them, and they had certainly declined in different regions, like big cities in the early '90s.
But people like Alan Greenspan and mortgage brokers and all sorts of people kept repeating this mantra - house prices have never declined.

And so based on that idea that they had never declined, people got it into their heads that they never could decline, and so they bid up prices incredibly high, which then made it a certainty that they would have to decline.
All right, so you had that kind of side of the equation, but then there's this other side, the multiplier effect which you write about, and I thought oh, now I kind of get it.
When you talk about these leveraged accounts, can you explain that part of it?
Absolutely.
So if you want to make, say, a $100 million investment, there are a couple of ways to do it.
One way is to put up $100 million, and if the investment rises by, say, one percent, $1 million, you've made a 1 percent return.
Do you think that scientists too could learn things from your play?
She's the first one to go to college in our family, by the way.
Just throwing it out there.
David, yesterday sorrow quickly gave way to mounting anger on the part of the students when they found out that the university did not warn them after the first shooting.
It took nearly two hours to warn them.
Is that anger still there today?
There's a real range of opinions.
And some people feel like if the university had acted faster, they might have saved lives.
But a lot of people, even if they're frustrated with the response, seem to say, look, you know, we never fathomed something like this happening.
And so our police officers on this campus did the best they could and we want to leave it at that.
So there seems to be some frustration, but people not feeling totally comfortable in criticizing at this point.
And David, what about news about the shooter?
Have you heard from anyone who knew him?
Have they established anything more about whether Seung-hui Cho lived there on campus?
And what about him?
Well, as we understand it, he was a permanent resident alien who had residence in the United States in Centreville, Virginia.
But he did actually live on campus, in a dorm.
It was not the dorm where the early shooting took place.
But we don't know much more, and certainly hopefully some more details will come out later.

But we know that they believe he was the gunman in the second shooting, the more deadly one, and they're assuming but not willing to say with certainty that he was the shooter in the earlier gunfire at the dormitory.
NPR's David Greene from the campus of Virginia Tech in Blacksburg, where a convocation over yesterday's shootings is about to begin.
David, thank you.
My pleasure.
From NPR News, it's DAY TO DAY.
The controversy over Don Imus' remarks about the women's basketball team at Rutgers has now hit the bottom line.
One media insider is calling for Imus to be fired.
Bruce Gordon made that call.
He's the former head of the NAACP.
He is also on the board of directors of CBS, which owns Imus' show.
Now advertisers are pulling their support from his show.
Here to talk about the business side of this gathering storm is Bob Moon of MARKETPLACE.
Hi, Bob.
Hey, Alex.
Bob, exactly how much money does the Imus show bring in?
Well, there are several media reports out there today, Alex, estimating that ""Imus in the Morning"" rakes in more than $20 million a year for CBS Radio.
The cable channel MSNBC pays CBS to carry the program as well.
And the New York Times reports that when you add up the ad revenue from MSNBC and the various local affiliates for Imus, it exceeds $50 million every year.
So there's a lot of money at stake here, although so far, only a handful of advertisers have pulled out, and perhaps only temporarily.
The office supply chain Staples, Proctor and Gamble, Bigelow Tea, those are the major names to announce suspensions of their advertising.
But we spoke to veteran media business expert Porter Bibb at Mediatech Capital Partners, and he points out a lot will depend on how long this lasts.
If you read between the lines, the advertisers have basically pulled their advertising for two weeks, the same period that Don Imus has been suspended.
And all of the advertisers, as far as I've been able to discern, have said they're going to wait and review the situation to see whether they'd put their advertising back on ""Imus in the Morning.
